H0.text: Space to move is the reason the student cuts holes in the top of a plastic container that holds soil as a home for worms.

H1.text: Air to breathe is what the worms need, so the student cuts holes in the top of the plastic container that holds soil to make a home for them.

H2.text: Sunlight to grow is needed by the worms in the soil the student places in a plastic container, so the student cuts holes in the top of the container.

H3.text: Sound to communicate is what the worms need, prompting the student to cut holes in the top of the plastic container of soil that serves as their home.

A4.text: The earthworm's burrowing creates a multitude of channels through the soil and is of great value in maintaining the soil structure, enabling processes of aeration and drainage.

A5.text: Permaculture co-founder Bill Mollison points out that by sliding in their tunnels, earthworms 'act as an innumerable army of pistons pumping air in and out of the soils on a 24-hour cycle (more rapidly at night)'.
